title: Making An Effective Graph
text:
During class this week, we learned how to create bar charts and discussed what makes a graph an effective tool to communicate data.
To do this, I made a bar chart showing UNL’s top 10 majors by students in 2024.
First, I loaded the libraries I needed and started with a dataset of all UNL majors.

library(tidyverse)
library(tidycensus)
library(janitor)


majors24 <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/datajournalismfiles/enrollment2024.csv") |> clean_names()

After loading the data and cleaning up the columns with clean_names(), I had to prepare the data for our chart. By filtering out any rows I didn’t need and sorting all specializations into their respective majors, I was left with the two rows I needed for the bar chart.

topmajors24 <- majors24 |> 
  filter(major_name != "Total") |> 
  group_by(major_name) |> 
  summarize(
    total_majors = sum(headcount)
  ) |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  top_n(10, wt=total_majors)

I threw all the code into ggplot and made a decent graph.

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data = topmajors24, aes(x=reorder(major_name, total_majors), weight = total_majors)) +
  coord_flip()








In the end, the chart was weak. It doesn’t tell an interesting story or communicate an insight. A better graph would compare the top 10 majors by students between several years or show us the majors with the lowest student counts .
